text: On cask. Pours dark brown-black with light beige head. Roasted malt with some coffee notes with dark fruit.

I do like a good British dark ale. Dark brown with some ruby glints. Body is on the fuller side of medium and frothy. Full of roasted malts bringing molasses, digestive biscuit and nuts. Hedgerow flavours from the hops. Slightly soapy, otherwise great.

Pours clear, ruby brown colour with a medium sized creamy beige head. Aroma is dark malt and dark fruit. Similar taste, some sweetness and roastiness in the malt, more dark fruit and a nuttiness. Mild bitterness in a slightly watery finish. Not bad.

Cask. Small off-white head atop clear garnet body. Aroma is moderately sweet, currant, some caramel, light orange/earthy. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, light bread, currant. Light-medium body, light stickiness.
Couple of pints at the Old Fox Felling. Russet Brown with a creamy off white head. Toffee aroma, fruit and nut toffee flavour, hint of overripe banana and farmyard. Creamy mouthfeel. Tasty..

Draft at Churchkey. After a night of over the top hops, finishing with a "mild" malt bomb. How tasty! Dark brown, light bodied, huge frothy head (cask). Sweet nutty malts in both aroma and taste, silky smooth. This ones all about the taste, pure and simple. Very simple, very tasty.

Bottle from Ocado. Light brown/ruby, very translucent with a small off-white head. Light chocolate malt aroma with some toasty notes. Fresh sweet malty taste with a surprisingly dry finish. More chocolate and a hint of sarsaparilla in the aftertaste. Very basic stuff, although well made and refreshing.

Hand pump at Ma Che in Rome-Italy. Dark cherry skin clear pour, frothy foam with reddish highlights. Nice. Nose: nice feel of English malts, red fruit, a bit roast and pinch of leather. Mouth: properly mild, medium roast malty a bit sweet in a clean and easy body, bitter finish cleaning the mouth! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap, not cask, at Euston Tap. Black. Mild hop aroma. For a dark sour, this is surprisingly well hopped. Some roasted malt flavor and dry, bitter hops. It is bitter enough that it is not the most drinkable mild i have had, but i do like it.

Cask. Appearance is very dark ruby, almost black. Aroma- dark fruit, Christmas cake, dark malts, slight roastiness. Taste- more dark fruit, coffee, malty, roast malt. Slightly watery towards the finish.

Pint at the WIndsor. Faint aroma of smoke and coffee. Pours dark with a tight white head. Some roast on the taste, nice and dry. Its nothing ground breaking but it is a damn good pint. Says "mild" as a style - nope. Its a dark lager/stout crossover in my book. Like++
Coca cola with tan head. Cappuchino aroma. Slight acidic, roasted coffee and earthy finish. Good!

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2016 On Cask at the Tartan Tavern in Oban. Pours deep dark ruby brown with an off white head. Malty nose. Dark malts. Dark fruits. A nice Mild with a relatively full bitterness. Fruity. Rounded. Nice.

Bottle 50cl. Poured into shaker. Clear amber brown, good creamy tan head, good retention and lacing; aroma roasted malts, burned caramel, chocolate, dried dark fruits; taste medium sweet and light heavy bitter, roasty, milk chocolate, fruity; bittersweet finish, roasty and light fruity bits; medium body, texture watery to oilt, soft carbonation; a mild ale with a stoutlike feel.

500ml bottle. Clear dark reddy brown colour with a very smooth creamy off-white head, which quickly becomes rather thin. Malty aroma, lightly roasted, berry fruits, hoppy hints. Taste of roasted malts with hints of berry fruits, leading to a long bitter finish with a hop bite.

Tasted @ monthly 1st Wednesday tasting @ brewpub De Molen. Clear amber pour, thin off-white head. Aroma of spicy malts, some licorice, British yeast and some crispy hops. Flavor is quite bitter, spicy and smooth. Nice and subtle brew, but quite powerful for the low abv.

Aroma:

Malts, chocolate, roasted malts and hops.

Appearance:

Turbid ruby/brown beer with a slight off-white head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium sweet with malts and chocolate; ends slightly bitter with roasted malts and hops.

Hand-pulled cask pint in Ye Olde Fighting Cocks, Oakengates Shropshire on 19th Dec 2015. Very pleasant Mild with a ruby red hue to its darkness, the head a full and lasting creamy head. Malts rule the flavouring and in the nose also, not sweet though, this is a nicely balanced beer with enough going on to be interesting.

[7714-20150924] Tap. Carbon dust and mineral grain aroma. Clear, bright dark amber body with a big long-lasting foamy off-white head. Bitter rocky grains flavour. Medium body. Tasty. (7/4/7/3/15) 3.6
(@ Holborn Whippet, London, England)
500ml bottle. One of my favourite beers. Aroma is caramel and berries. Flavour medium sweet and lightly bitter. Light carbonation and smooth on the palate. A terrific ale.

50cl bottle at home from Biernavigatie.nl. Body is clear brown, head is big, beige, rocky, average lasting, excellent lacing. Nose is chocolate, flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, herbs, light spices, dried fruits. Medium sweet, medium to heavy roasty bitter. Finish is long lasting roasty medium bitter, cocoa, roasted malt, watery side taste. Medium to full body, dry texture, average carbonation. Quite easy dessert beer, strong simple taste.
Poured a clear brown with a white head. The aroma is weak grassy hop. The flavour is weak bitter with a roasted malt. Very watery palate.

2015-09-24. Crisp mahogany brown body with a nice foamy beige head. Aroma is mild, dusty malt, English malt character that I still lack a better deScriptor for, lightly fruity. Flavour is pleasant, nice malty core, good balancing bitterness light citrusy hops in the finish longer with hoppy bitterness. Smooth average bodied palate, soft carbonation. 3+ Nice stuff. On cask at Holborn Whippet, London, UK.

500ml bottle from Turners Abbeydale Road - Dark nut brown body with a small light beige lacing head. The nose has a mild dark malty aroma. A little bit of coffee grunt and some herbal toffee stuff going on. Dark malty taste and a little bit of bitterness that dries the mouth on the finish. Got a bit boring towards the end.
Cask at SRAF. Deep ruby. Nose is ripe fruits, toffee, wood. Taste is dry toffee, bitter fruits.

Cerveza de color caramelo oscuro con una espuma espesa y cremosa. Aroma a caramelo con notas frutales. Sabor afrutado con malta caramelo y su toque de amargura del lúpulo en el retrogusto. buena cerveza.

500 ml bottle drank at Les Vignerons. (No proper tasting notes, overall impression only) Dark ruby red with a small light beige head. Mesmerizing and complex nose: hazelnuts, cocoa powder, watered down coffee. Very clean and inviting. Great drinkability, just enough taste to keep you interested. Mildly bitter, not too watery, a true session ale. Thumps up!

This is very reminiscent of my own attempts at home brew, especially in colour, which I finished the last bottle of last week and Im missing already. I think mightve been that colour from caramelising the malt extract in the boil pot though. The colour is dark reddish brown with a light brown head. The aroma is warm and honeyish. The taste turns into bitter hoppy with a late slight malt flavour.

Bottle. Pours a mahogany brownish red with a non lasting beige head. Aroma of chocolate, hint of blackcurrant. Taste is of chocolate, dark fruits, hint of bitter coffee, fig. Medium to light carbonation, slightly oily mouthfeel.
Bottle from Fyne. Dark ruby, full creamy off white head. Fruity malts and chocolate raisin. Medium body, medium carbonation. Coffee and dark berries. Dry and bitter finish. Really rather good.
Bottle @ benzai. Dark amber to red colour with a small off-white head. Smells hops, fresh, slightly cedar wood. Tastes sweetish, bitter, slightly toasted, wood. Medium body, soft carbo.

Bottle @ weekly tasting shared with Dutchdrebus. Clear dark amber to reddish color, average sized beige head. Smell and taste lightly malts, a hint of blackcurrant is indeed detectable, a hint of hops, lightly bitter. Decent body and carbonation. Not bad.

Many thanks to Sean for this bottle.  Smooth and malty beginning. Nice roasted malt, dry, with a fruity Ale-aroma. Nice full body, highly drinkable, nice intense malty-dry bitterness in the aftertaste. Fresh, smooth-roasty-malty, great.

0,5 l bottle from Scotia Spirit, Cologne; best before may 2015. Clear, dark brownish red with a thin, soapy, slowly diminishing, tan head. Rich, malty aroma of dark fruits like blackcurrant, dried plums and dried cranberries, accompanied by hints of coffee. Sweetish, slightly less fruity taste with the coffee coming a bit more to the fore. Very short, gently bitter finish. Almost thin bodied though not yet watery, soft carbonation. Very aromatic while lacking a bit of taste but really impressive considering the low abv. Enjoyable!
500ml bottle from brewery via eebria. Colour is deep Amber, with a thick creamy white head. The aroma roasted malt, and chocolate. The taste follows on nicly with more of the same. With a dry finish.
Cask in the brewery bar. Deep ruby with a frothy cream head. Jammy red fruit and roasty malt flavour. Rich and tasty. Good.
Bottle. Red fruit tea with toffee and floral hops added. Some raisins. Soft mouthfeel, quite bitter finish for the style, with hints of coffee and roast. Very tasty mild.
Cask at falls of dochart inn. Sweet roasted malts, fruity berry taste, light bitterness.
Bottle shared with McTapps. Mild and light one with some hops, barley and rye. Fruity moments with balanced carbo and easy drinkability. Fine one.

Bottle from Scotia Spirit in Cologne. The beer pours out in a deep dark brown colour with low head and medium body.Aroma of fresh hops, thyme and herbs. Taste of fresh hops, light malt, wood, torf, barley, bread and wild herbs. Mild and smooth finish. Quaffable and easy to enjoy.
Bottle at home. Pours ruby red with tan head. Light Hoppy nose. Sweet toffee flavour with light bitterness. Very light body. Okay.

Bottle at YNWA Kolding. Low but lasting off-white head. Clear dark red brown body. Dried fruit roasted malt caramel raisin aroma. Roasted malt coffee flavor with a nice hops bitterness, high carbonation and a long dry bitter finish.
Bottle. Black colour, with red reflexes, small head with good lacing. Aroma is caramel and herbs. Medium bitterness, bitter finish. Good.
Bottle. Pours hazy deep amber with a medium creamy beige head. Aroma is toasted and dark fruity. Toasted malty and hoppy flavor.

Ready hazel fine English hoppy relaativ low percentage of beer. Slightly bitter vital kick to the back of the tongue.
cobweb foam.
Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Moderate malty and light hopy aroma. Moedrate bitter flavor. Average mdoerate bitter finish. oily palate. Nice.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; clear chestnut brown pour with a frothy off white head, dark fruit aroma, taste has sweet malts with some delightful underlying tart dark fruit action, a little caramel.
light malty aroma,golden, clear, off white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, oily feel, lively,
Nice amber coloured and clear. Has a hoppy aroma, lightly dark fruits and light bread. Flavor starts sweet, malty, light bread and finish moderate bitter. Creamy, dry texture.

Cask at Craft Beer Co Covvy G, 23/05/14.
Dark mahogany brown with a well appointed tan head that dissipates in time to a solid covering.
Nose is caramel, vanilla, hoppy jacket, light smoke, toffee fudge.
Taste comprises dark berry fruit, caramel, light smoke, dark malt.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with an earthy hop presence.
Decent hoppy mild.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: (draught) pours a clear amber-ruby colour with a frothy beige head. aroma of dark chocolate and blackberries, with a hint of yeast, hazelnuts, herbal hops and earth. flavour is more dark fruit and some fudge, slightly tart, with notes of herbal hops, spruce and a heavy-bitter finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.
Cask @ Borefts. Fruity hops, some malt, a touch of yeast. Full malt flavour with a medium bitter hop note and loads of fruits. Nice one.

Cask at the Euston tap. Dark brown on colour with a thin light tan head. Small aroma, slight tart fruits and nutty malt. Flavour is medium toast malts, tart berries and a weird spicy veg flavour that I cant put my finger on. Hints of clean roast lingers. Good condition slightly strange put pretty drinkable.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein dunkel bernsteinfarbenes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, fruchtig, Beeren. Geschmack sehr röstmalzig, schokoladig, fruchtig.
Cask at the blue blazer. Pours clear Britten, thin off-white head. Light toffee and herbal aromas. Taste has toffee sweetness, faint bitterness. Clean finish. Good.
Light brown. Light toffee with some fruit, nice light fruit-forward amber ale. Drinkable with some complexity.

From cask @ Borefts 2013. This one has a deep dark nut brown appearance with a small light beige and sidesticking top. The nose has a mild dark malty aroma. A little bit of coffee grunt and some toffee herbal thing. A bit mild on the nose perhaps. Its quite gentle and mild in the taste also. Soft malty biscuits traces. Something dark malty and a little bit of bitterness that dries the mouth on the finish. Easy, not to exciting though. 28.09.2013

Aroma: roasted malt, some chocolate. Appearance: brown, frothy medium head. Taste: medium sweet. Palate: bitters getting quite dominant, medium long dry finish. Overall: nice Mild Ale, surprisingly different from the traditional Mild. Pint at the Craft Beer Co. Clerkenwell, London.
Borefts Beer Festival 2013. Dark copper with a small off-white head. Aroma of dried fruit, toffee and red berries. Sweetish, clean malty flavour with fruity notes. Pleasant drinking

Dark beer with thin white head
aroma is sweet grain
taste is malty with a dry bitter finish that lasts
a bit thin and a bit gassy strange palate for a cask beer
a ok beer

Dark ruby color with a average tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel and something that I dont know. Flavor is Malty and sweet as caramel witha sharp bitterness. Medium body with a light carbonation and a dry bitter finish. Very good surprise.

Clear brown amber colour, off-white head. Aroma of hops, malts, light fruity. Malty flavour, light bitter hops. Low on the CO2. Light bitter, bready finish.
(From draught @ BBF V, 2013. Thanks for sharing, ratebeer crew!)
Pint at Milnes bar in Rose Street, Edinburgh. Quite a dark brown with quite some head.

Bottled, BB Jan 2015, large sample. Clear ruby color, medium light brown head. Aroma is fruity, roast, blackcurrant, earthy hop, toast, caramel, dark fruit. Biscuity taste, bit sweet, bit bitter, dry.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 28.09.2013, cask @ Borefts:
Tiny bubbly head. Aroma is slightly roasted grain, caramel, hay, herbs, hints of chocolate. Taste is slightly watery and grassy, roasted grain, hay, coffee, grass, cocoa. Longlasting bitterness, dry mouthfeel. Boring.
Draught at Borefts BeerFest 2013. Clear red/brown - offwhite head. Roasted, tea hoppy, herbal hoppy, grassy, ok malty, toasted, light dark berries, zesty bitter finish.
Draft at BBF13Clear brown. Small fading tan head. Not much aroma. And rather tasteless as well. Mild bitterness, some chocolate, some roasted malts. Mwah.
Tap at Borefts. Dark reddish colour with off-white head. Mild malty aroma. Hoppy, slightly sweet taste. Light body.
Cask. Amber coloured. Unclear. Small brown head. ARoma. grass, caramel, spice. Flavour. herbs, caramel, some sweetness and spice.MEdium boied. Ends grassy bitter.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2014 On cask at troon beer festival 2013 ammened by cask at geordies byre ayr 15/2/14 deep red bitter that has a reasonably clean light fruity flavour some plums citrus and malt undertone some coffee notes and some slight blackcurrant better than average bitter
Draught @ Borefts Beer Festival, 2013. Pours amber with a bubbly head. Caramel, fruit and mild diacetyl. Thin.
Mooie donkerbruine caramelkleur met een aardig kraag. Hop en chocolade geur. Beetje waterig en weinig smaak.
Cask at Borefts Bier Festival 2013. Bitter and medium to dry taste, a bit average

Cask at Borefts Bier Festival 2013. 
Clear orange-red coloured with a small off-white head.
Fruity aroma of caramel, hops and grass.
Fruity and light roasted flavour of caramel, hops and grapefruits.
Dry hoppy finish.
Borefts 2013 - Dark brown, no head. Thin, watery body. Smooth taste with rich, fruity malts.

Pours coper amber beer with a good white head.
Smells sweet, herbs and spices.
Tastes watery, very mild with a bitter finish. Odd taste but very balanced.
Dry texture, thin body and an average carbo.
On tap at Borefts 2013. Clear darkish brown with a small pale head. Aroma is toffee, honey, subtle hint of pine. Thin bodied, bitter on the palate. Taste is burnt sugar, roasted malts, pine. Meh

On tap at BBF 13. Brown colour, no head. Aroma of toast, chocolate, light woody, hint of spice, nuts. Flavour lacks a bit of the vital spark, a bit watery, light fruity, chocolate, light spicy, nutty, hoppy finish. OK.
Draft at Borefts 2013. Pours hazy brown with a small off-white head. Aroma has a bit of caramel, toast and herbal hops. Taste has some malts, grassy hops with a medium bitter finish.

Sampled cask @ Borefts 2013. Amber orange, clear with no head. Nose is oily, malts, some brown sugar, slight sweetness. Taste is bitter herbs, oily, some burned sugar, light herbs, light grass. Watery, cask body. Not bad or anything but far from exiting or invigorating.
Draft at BBF13. Pours clear brown with a small tan head. Aroma of malt and light spice. Flavour is light sweet and moderate to heavy bitter. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Bottle 0,5ltr: Dark brown coloured brew with an grassy and citrus hoppiness of taste, quite dry bitter appearance of taste.
Tap at Borefts 2013. Poured a clear dark chesnut brown with a round off-white head. The aroma is weak grassy hop. The flavour is weak bitter with a liqourice roasted malt, slightly watery palate.

Draft @ Borefts 2013. Has a clear brownish pour with a light, bubbly thin off white head. Aroma is floral, citric and full of hoppy influences. Flavor is quite bitter and herbal. Thin, watery mouthfeel. Short bitter finish. Decent brew which is full flavoured for such low abv.

Cask at CBC Brixton. Pours a dark reddy amber with a thin off white head. Aroma is minimal - a hint of toffee, bit of smoke, not a great deal more. Fairly light body, a little thin. It's a little bland - woody, a bit smokey with a touch of treacle. OK. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Brown good head fruity malty little caramel light body noci hoppy taste medium bitter 
Mogano quasi scura schiuma media buona persistenza leggero fruttato non molto corpo tostute delicare didcreta nota maltata buon amaro luppolato

August 29, 2013 - hand-pull cask at Craft Beer Co (Clerkenwell). Clear deep burnt copper with and average lasting frothy tan head. Aroma On draught of dry resin, leafy bitterness, somewhat didnt nutty malt, and some sort of tart fruit, a little. No alcohol. Taste has much less bitterness, plenty of lightly tart roast malt. Slick, somewhat still, astringent, with a squeaky aftertaste. Interesting after many golden ales.

Nice clear red-brown with a light beige head. Aroma of malt, nutty, a bit plain. Taste is light sweet, bitter, sour. Oily, thin texture, light carbonation, a bit watery. OK but a bit boring to be honest, I think I was expecting a bit more...
Dark ruby, thin white head, nice lacing. Fruity, estery, black current nose. Huge malt palette, dry, summer fruits flavour. Flat carbonation, smooth, dry ale palette. Finish is short, malty and dry.
Cask handpull at The Ale House, Chelmsford. Pours a dark ruby brown colour with off white head. Aroma of raisins, and roasted malts. Rich and medium/full bodied, minimal carbonation. Enjoyable.
Dark beer with a malt scent. Both malt and hop in the flavour and the finish is similar.  Not as much body as I might have liked.
Pours auburn with creamy head.  Aroma of citrus peel and fruit.  Taste is quite hoppy, but with a thinner taste than I expected.  A good beer from Fyne Ales.

(Cask at Craft Beer Co Islington, London, 26 Apr 2013) Ruby red colour with foamy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with caramel, red fruit and a touch of black-currant. Malty, fruity taste with notes of red fruit, caramel, black-currant and a gentle, spicy bitterness in the finish. Medium body, with a certain malt sweetness. Well balanced and quite nice.
Pint at York Tap.  Dark brown, with a good creamy head.  Smooth, lightly hopped dark ale, subtle.  Goes down very well. Very light chocolate malt aroma, faint.  Pretty good.  Dry hop finish.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2013 Pours a rich mahogany with ample foamy tan head that lingers. Aroma- bitter, slight caramel. Taste is sweet start, middle of berries (cherry?) into wood-tasting hops which morph into a dry spiciness with caramel and herbs. Bitter dry finish with hints of wood. Very complex and interesting. Great Scottish ale. Needs to be paired with food (pot pie?) to relieve the bitterness between sips.

500ml bottle. ar: caramel malt with berry. ap: clear mahogany, thick head, subsiding. ta:  medium sweetness, medium bitterness. pa: medium body, creamy texture, average carbonation. Finish: lingering malt. Overall: top quality Scottish Heavy 80/-.

Says mild, but this also has the dryness of a stout. Pours deep brown/red, with lots of carbonation. Aroma I get is something like bitter chocolate orange. The palate is drying, with a real bitter edge. The hops give a citrus edge. Nice, but needs snacks with it to get the tastebuds going between sips!

500ml bottle from The Real Ale Warehouse, drunk today. I first tried this on cask at the Tigh an Truish Inn, on the Isle of Seil, a few years ago, but have only just got around to rating it. Clear, dark mahogany. Pours good, creamy, light brown head, with fine bubbles, lasting very well. Light carbonation. Aroma - Spicy, sweet toffeeish malt and satisfying, intensely berryish, tangy hops, with some warm, herbiness and a bit metallic. Taste - Mid dry. Intense herby, berry flavoured hops; almost slightly sour medicinal herby taste, which balances out well with the slightly sweet, toffeeish, dark malts and complements the dry finish well. Some slight cola spice & fruit sweetness. Dry, mid-bitter finish, with some slight lingering, pleasant herby & berry fruit hop flavours. A touch of metallic aftertaste too, though. Mid body for the style, bit creamy, bit astringent. A distinctive dark ale, with warm, satisfying flavours and a refreshing, crisp finish. Still good, but its definitely much better on cask, in an old Inn, on a tiny, rocky Scottish island that sticks out into the Atlantic.

Bottle from CBB. It poured a wonderful light amber red with a thick tan head of foam. It is VERY easy to drink with a malty aroma, sweet taste and a smooth dry mildly bitter finish. Its a great session beer and a nice beer for Japanese ladies-sweet, easy to drink and different from a boring bland lager!
500 ml bottle. Pours a dark mahogany with full head. Aromas of toffee, golden raisins, and roasted malts. Flavors of malts, toast, light fruitiness, and hops. Tasty for a mild.
Cask by handpump at West Kirk, Ayr - clear dark red brown, thin bubbly beige head, berry fruit aroma, blackcurrant, bitter taste, bitter aftertaste

([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */)  Amber colour. Aroma/taste caramel malts, hoppy berry fruits (D13)

500 ml bottle. L0311. BB May 2013. From the Fyne Ales Brewery in Cairndow, Scotland.
Clear dark reddish brown colour with small to average sized light tan head. Chocolate and roasted malt combined with nice shade of hoppy bitterness. Flavour is hoppy bitterness and roasted malt with notes of chocolate, resin and pine. Excellent. This could be Black IPA. Tasty and balanced. This must be the best Mild Ale Ive ever tasted. Nice hoppy bitterness in aftertaste. This brewery really knows what they are doing.

Pours a dirty ruby colour with a light crema head, rich dark fruits, dates and honey, tastes of nice earthy hops touch of bitter chocolate. Quite a creamy mouthful. Nice beer 

via Beer Buddy
50 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK. Medium brown, frothy head. Chocolate and citrus aroma. Somewhat sweet with prune and raisin flavors. Finish is hoppy, with more chocolate.
Cask at Marine Hotel, Stonehaven. Tried it on consecutive nights.  Nice hop / malt balance, slight haze, lovely aroma, Pretty decent pint
Bottle. Dark ruby/chestnut with lasting creamy beige head. Rich berries dominate the aroma; some port, mineral water. Taste is somewhat tart berries, bittering hops, and light chocolate.

500 ml bottle, from a potential importer. ABV is 4.4%. Chestnut colour, large to moderate beige head, leaves a nice lacing in the glass. Pleasant aroma of mildly roasted malts, hints of coffee and caramel, but not sweetish. The flavour has first a medium dry mild roastiness, also some fruity notes with hints of blackcurrants, and ends in a more distinct roastiness and dry hoppy bite, Very good - the best bottled beer Ive had from Fyne Ales so far. Got my "Aye!" vote for import to Norway.

Cask @ The North Pole. Pours a lightly translucent brownish red with no head. The nose is pretty standard for a mild - nuts, some soft milk chocolate, cola and red fruits. The taste is mildly tangy vinous fruit, hints of coffee creamer, roasted malts and sweet chocolate. Well balanced, but a bit muted. Perhaps this isnt on top form? The bodys a bit watery. Light, easy to drink. Overall, fairly good. I like Fynes beers, so will have to return to this.
An excellent dark beer. Rich and full bodied. Hits the taste buds and wakes them up. Will do another .

Deep burgundy with a modest off-white head and lace. Aromas of malt, blackcurrant, caramel, hops, oak. Sweet and slightly sour on initial sip. You can certainly taste the hops and malt with the blackcurrant. There's an earthy, woody quality making Vital Spark a perfect autumn beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 12, 2014 The smell and even taste of turpentine means that you first back away. Then other flavors develop such as licorice, chocolate and black currants. A good ale, but far too dominant.

Bottle from myBrewerytap.com. Pours dark brown with a big spongy light tanned head. Aroma is herbal malty, with blackcurrant and minty notes. Taste is dry resiny hops,blackcurrant and herbs in the front seat. Lingering herbal and resiny, light sweet nutty malt mix. Very good, sharp and intriguing.

26th January 2010On tap somwhere! Clear dark amber beer. Light dry palate. Full on flavours! Noticeably hoppy but with black tea that would be served in the Far East - aromatic and floral. Finishes dry. Unusual and bears some resemblance to the better Black IPAs.

Cask @ Bandstand Bar, Nairn 050612
Dark brown, frothy off white tan head, good lacing
Aroma - roasted malts, soft cocoa, dark malts, quite a lot of cocoa, but not a lot on the nose
Taste - roasted malts, dark fruity malts, dark caramel malts, bitter fruity hops, lot of flavour
Palate - soft carb, medium body, soft bitter roast palate. Finish - bit over-lingering bitter roast palate
Overall - Quite a good pint, but it didnt impress me that much

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2015 Bottle. Dark ruby body with a thick lasting tan head. Lots of sticky lacing. Aroma of berries, coffee beans, Coca-Cola, caramelised sugar and floral hops. Flavour of sweet chocolatey malt, liquorice, plum and orange. Medium body with a smooth, slightly oily palate. Soft carbonation. Delicious. Possibly my favourite Fyne Ales beer.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2013 Pours dark brown with an off white head. Medium body. Roasted coffe aroma, some licorice, wet wood. Tastes of coffee, some black pepper in the aftertaste. Tried with mom and dad in Brighton after picking these bottles up in Canterbury in 2012.

Tried again at BBF 2013.
Yum. Tastes gorgeous, but it doesnt linger for long. I could drink lots through and am looking forward to more from Fyne :)
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are rich hops, flowers, peach, pine caramel, nuts and malt. Yummy!
Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and mdoerate hoppy - citrus. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 010512
Bottle, 4.4%. Dark amber with medium tan head. Aroma is malt, fruit, hops, citrus and grapefruit. Flavour is malt, fruit, hops, citrus, little sweet, grapefruit and medium bitter.
Dark ruby with fluffy whitehead, sweet caramel, apples and rasins on the nose. Tastes of a caramel flavoured lattewith a gentle bitterness to finish.

3/IV/2012 - on cask @ Cask Pub & Kitchen (London)  - BB: n/a (2012-316) 
Clear red to purple brown beer, small solid creamy light beige head, pretty adhesive, nice lacing in the glass. Aroma: very fruity, ripe forest fruits, caramel, pretty sweet. MF: soft carbon, full body. Taste: pretty fruity, some citrus, ripe summer fruit, then mocha, some caramel. Aftertaste: bitter hoppy, burned toast, mocha, fruity touch, some coffee in the end.
Cask @ Craft. Pours clear dark ruby with decent head. Hoppy aroma. Citrus fruits, blackcurrant especially at the end, with malty base. More bitter than I expected. Very nice pint!
Cask at HWBF. Aroma of hops and berries. Taste is caramel malt and more berry sharpness. Very delicious.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2013 Quite dark in colour. Hoppy, quite a dry bitterness and some hints of herbs, tobacco and grass. Enjoyable beer with good character.
Amber colored pour. Small white/off-white head. Lots of lacing. Big malty hoppy aroma. Big malty hoppy taste. Slight bitterness. Very quaffable.

AROMA: floral, spruce, herbs, fruity
APPEARANCE: red, clear, frothy disappears slowly
TASTE: light sweetness, medium bitterness
PALATE: medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, bitter, long finish
OVERALL: well-rounded red ale that has a full body for such a low ABV, nice sweetness followed by bitterness then a sweet aftertaste. Interesting aromas without overpowering fruitiness.

Medium beige head. Deep brown barely translucent body. Light floral resiny perfumy aroma with gooseberry malty notes. Dry-sweet nutty earthy caramelly taste with resiny perfumy notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, smooth mouthfeel. Dry nutty caramelly floral aftertaste with resiny metallic notes. Nice and extremely drinkable. (0.5l bottle, Tre Små Rum, Göteborg.)

A dark brown beer witha a mdium and beige head. Aroma is nice and interesting, toffee, some liquirice and spicyness. Taste is slightly toffeeish and roasted, wooden and herbs, overally quite dry. Medium- bodied, nice carbonation, quite light, but nice to drink. Quite enjoyable and complex beer, something interesting (blackcurrants?) and unique in the aroma.

Tumman ruskea, mutta punertava olut. Muodostaa päälleen valkoisen vaahdon. Tuoksu on marjainen, toffeinen ja paahtunut. Maussa on marjaisuutta ja paahtunutta mallasta. Jälkimaku on kuivan katkera. Keskiverto määrä hiilihappoja. Mukavan juotava ja maukas olut.

Soft  fruity aroma . Amber to dark colour . Good mix of pale  and crystal malt .. Very clean hop profile .  Very gentle bitterness . Very refreshing on the palate .  Small bubble on the tongue . Impressed for mild ale . A real winner .

Bottle. Pours a deep red/brown, with a nice red corona. Off-White fluffy head. A roasty nose, but a mouthful of chocolate-coffees mixed with mild blackcurrants. Theres a hint of a sprucey hop, and the finish is long, bitter and dry. Rich, complex and a real enjoyable experience.

500 ml bottle.  BBE 07/2012.
Pours a dark amber colour with a thick, slightly creamy and natural white colour. Aroma of slightly toasted malts, floral hops and light citrus. Flavour of toasted malts, fruits, bread, strong floral hops and nuts. Medium bodied and probably the richest mouthfeel for such a low ABV beer. FInishes nutty and bitter. Very nice.

On cask at brewers pride, ossett. Pours ruby with a white head. A smoky start which is very bitter, levels off to a smooth dark fruit finish. Smooth.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

from le Mondial de la Bière 2011, Strasbourg - clear reddish-brown beer under a solid creamy and persistent beige foam; nice lace; toasted aroma of biscuit and caramel; moderate malt backbone and a low carbonation; quite dry and bitter with a long earthy and cookie-like finish

50cl bottle from Bierzwerg. Poured dark amber with a lasting dirty white head. Hoppy, very fruity aroma with some caramel as well. Flavor is caramel, fudge-like candy notes as well as fresh fruity, hoppyness. Long lasting caramel finish, slightly bitter also. Medium bodied. Another great beer from this brewery.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with hints of red and a 1 finger head. Dark fruit, bready malt aroma. Rich dark fruits, toffee and great maltiness in the flavour. The finish begins with some bitter, citurs hops before rich fruit takes over again. This beer had great amount of flavour considering its relatively low abv.

50 cl bottle @ home, BBE 06/2012
Aroma is rather nice with fruity hops, bready malt and hints of vanilla. Flavour has bready malt, fruity hops, some vanilla and peanuts. Nutty, dry and leathery finish. Very nice for a 4,4% ABV beer.

First tasted this in the Three Judges, Glasgow in April 2004. Cask, handpump dispense. Ruby black in colour with a thin white head. Juicy date fruit in the long malty aroma. Thin but creamy mouthfeel and good lacing. Complex dark malts deliver a rich maltloaf base with syrupy raisin fruit and caramel notes evident in the mouth. Slight prickle of hop resins give a short bitter bite to the aftertaste. Buisness as usual as strong malt returns in the fruity finish.

Bottle: Clear, ruby-amber coloured, creamy and stable off-white head, dry nose: dried dark fruits and a solid hoppy base, some chocolate detectable; solid dry bitter-sweet flavour,almost medium bodied, soft MF; dry toasty finish, dark fruits again plus a lingering bitterness. A very fine Ale (no pun!), but I have my doubts, thst this is a mild Ale

500ml bottle pours brown in color with some reddish hues and about 2 fingers of off-white head which leaves some nice thick lacing on the side of the glass.  Aroma is fruity with some light roasted malts and some citrus and grassy hops.  Taste is light roasty malt bitterness with some caramel and fruity sweetness and a pleasing citrusy and grassy hop bitterness.  This is a fine dark mild ale which is a fine tasting experience.

Bottle at home, from my Maudite glass. Pours clear brown, with a garnet flash. 1-finger white head, spotty lacing, approaching fine. Nose is toffee, dark fruit (berries?) and a clean snap of citrus hops. Flavours are spicy and round, with some berryish notes, roots, toffee, smoke, and again, some nice, spritzy hops. Earthy finish. Overall, a remarkably pleasant session brew.

Bottle. Dark copper with a great rich head. Nice moderate malt aroma with some light toffee. A nice light malt, toffee flavour like a scotch lite. These are some Fyne Ales. Made for watching sports and staying relatively sober.

Vital Spark pours out a beautiful burnished amber with a thick, foamy yellow head. Some thick, creamy lacing and no carbonation. The nose is simply lovely with a nice nutty roast and a light burnt note and a beautiful prominent hop. Notes of wood, grapfeuit, toffee, biscuits and grassy hops. The taste is surprisingly light with a sweet, nicely malted middle. A lovely roast, hints of hazelnut, liquorice, toffee and grass. Biscuity, chewy malts throughout. The finish has a light grapefruit bitterness with a lingering hop taste. Vital Spark is medium bodied with a somewhat thin mouthfeel and a creamy smooth drinking beer.

Bottled.
Deep amber, beige head. 
Very hoppy nose, malts, fruity, herbal, apricots, rye bread. 
Dry, medium body, high bitterness-. 
Fruity, hoppy taste, citrus fruits, rye bread, yeast, apricots, dried fruits. (2011-11-18)

Cask at the White Horse Old Ale festival 2011, Parsons Green, London. A ruby/brown coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Fruity, hoppy aroma. Tastes fruity, caramel, malty, hoppy. Good stuff from Fyne.

Cask at White Horse Parsons Green. It pours very dark ruby, with a decent beige head. The nose is wood, varnish and salted caramel. The taste is salted caramel, wood, leather, earth, ash, charcoal, dark fruit and roasted malt, with a long, dry finish. Medium body and soft carbonation. Great flavour for this %.

From bottle. Pours ruby/brown almost purple tinge to it, white head, looks great. Fairly weak aroma of fruit, lemon, plums, caramel. Tate has raisins, plum, caramel, slight chocolate. It is what it is....

Bottle from Bierzwerg. Dark red brown color with huge frothy beige head with nice lacing. Aroma of chocolate, grapefruit, marzipan, dark fruits. Taste, caramel, grapefruit, toffee. Nice long bittersweet finish. Drinkable.

Cask (gravity) - Norwich Beer Festival 2011. A clear chestnut brown coloured beer with a loose, bubbly medium sized & mostly lasting off-white to beige head. Delicate coffee, hints of roast, some dark fruit & juicy hop coming through. Fuller coffee & roast notes on the tongue with some yeast tones. Lingering-ish bitterness, slightly dry, light to medium body & a soft, smooth palate texture. A lovely drinkable mild with good balance and added hop spark.

Bottle. Dark amber, small to average and mostly diminishing light brown head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, caramel and some fruitiness, some citrus hoppyness and faint roasted malt. Body is medium, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, some caramel and some fruitiness, some citrus hoppyness and light roasted malt. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish, some caramel and some fruitiness, citrus and piney hoppyness, light roasted malt. Nicely hopped, fruity ale - bit too much caramel.

Bottled 500ml (BZ, BB 07/2012)
Dark amber-nut brown color, steady creamy beige head. Nutty malty aroma has hints of chocolate. Light bodied. Licorice, caramel, some hops in the finish. Nice salty aftertaste. Light but extremely well-balanced. Good one!

Bottle, consumed while watching PVRd football. Medium brown, clear, massive off-white head that leaves thick sheets of lace. Aroma initially is all grassy hops, but given some air time the underlying chocolate malt comes forward with nice nutty undertones. Flavours of cocoa and grassy hops, with a dry peanutskin bitterness in the finish. If this truly is a mild ale, then it is the hoppiest mild Ive yet tried. A really tasty session brew.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 500ml Bottle (Bishops Arms, Vasagatan, Stockholm) - Brown with red tinges. Fruity and hoppy aroma with notes of grapefruit, hops and caramel. Fruity, hoppy and slightly chocolatey taste with notes of grapefruit, marzipan, dried fruit and caramel. Nicely balanced and tasty, although I dont think its a mild which its currently listed as on this site.

500ml brown bottle. Chestnut brown colour, creamy and compact head, slightly off white in colour. Creamy lacing on the glass. Nose has nutty malt, bit of roast and chocolate. Flavour has dryish chocolate character, roasty end, lingering minerals and dark malts. Light bitterness, light body, soft carbonation. My first UK mild, surprised at the drinkabilty, blows away any domestic versions of the style Ive had and leaves me thinking I need to explore milds more, if only more were available here.

(bottle) Clear, ruby brown colour with a beige mid-sized foamy head. Dark malty, slightly roasted aroma with hints of cacao and caramel, accompanied by mildly fruity and herbal hops. Mildly sweet and slightly bitter flavour, light to almost medium bodied with a moderate carbonation. Roasty malt-character with caramel, dark chocolate and liquorice, again accompanied by delicately fruity and herbal hops; dry-ish sweet-bitter finish with rounded roasty malt and subtle fruity and spicy hops. Another gem from Argyll. 02.IX.11

50 cl bottle @ chriso.
Rated on 20110722.
Pours red colour with small head. Aroma of malts, mild fruits, berries and floral notes. Flavour of malts, fruits and some caramel. Balanced and smooth.
5315

Cask at George Hotel, Inveraray.  Near clear dark mahogany colour. Spicy hops are complimented by chocolate. Light-medium bodied with soft, vital mouthfeel. Lots of spicy hops, mild chocolaty toastiness with slight notes of wood. Long bitter finish. Absolutely delicously drinkable! Wish I had time for more than 3 pints! In my books Fyne Ales are Scotlands best brewery!

Bottled (from Beers Of Europe). Reddish amber colour, small beige head. Aroma is hoppy fruits, some floral notes as well as some slight berryish notes. Flavour is caramel malts, fudge, some berries, mild bitterness as well. Really pleasantly balanced.

Cask conditioned at The Pilot Inn, Berwick upon Tweed, Northumberland. Dark copper with white head. Good full roasty mats with a pleasant fruity, fleshy flavour. Hints of caramel and a finishing dryness, pretty decent.

A reddish brown ale with a thick brown head. In aroma, a surprsingly vinous malt with caramel, butterscotch, British hops, very nice. In mouth, a nicely roasted caramel malt, oily mouthfeel, nutty and lightly floral hops, surprising and quaffable. Bottle at Mondial 2011, June 10, 2011.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2011 On cask at Cloisters. A dark red beer with a decent tan head. Fruity, caramel and ginger aromas. Tastes of coffee and quite malty. Also fairly dry with some lingering bitterness.

Again at Cloisters. This time there was a huge valerian / celery aroma and flavour. Poured a  dark red- brown colour with a nice light tan head. Aroma also some grassy hops and alcohol with some caramel and alcohol flavours. A light roasty malt finish with some dryness again.

Verre de dégustation, dune bouteille, au Mondial 2011. Arômes de malt légèrement caramélisé. On note aussi une touche de fruits mûrs et un léger houblon fruité. Robe cuivrée et limpide, légère dentelle et effervescence moyenne. Très délicate en bouche, on remarque un léger malt fruité et chocolaté, présentant même des angles boisés et fumés. Très belle texture en bouche et caractère de fermentation très propre (on dirait presque une lager). Finale présentant une délicate amertume houblonnée. Très agréable.

My Bottom Line:
Toasted malts are balanced out by herbal hops and their bitterness in this prickly and hugely satisfying Mild Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam tops the russet brown.
-Light caramel undertones are perfectly harmonious with the rest of the flavor profile.
-The bitter hop finish is also nicely dry.
-Some nutty angles are also tasted. Nice malt complexity for such an easygoing brew.
-Hops dont take center stage in this one, but do contribute from aroma to finish.
-These guys obviously know how to bottle properly. Every bottled brew Ive had from them so far has been as pleasant as their cask ales.

Bottle.

Bottle at Mondial de la bière de Montréal 2011. Clear brown with a thin beige head with average retention. Aroma is caramel, nutty, toasted malt, brown sugar and earthy hops. Flavor is brown sugar, toasted malt, nutty, moderate herbal hops and a moderately bitter finish. Medium body and lively carbonation. Very nice malt profile!

Dark brown ale with red hue and nice head. The nose has faint pine and grapefruit. The taste is faint but bitter grapefruit and pine comes through again. The palate does not have enough body to balance the very bitter finish. Overall, Im not excited about this, its confusing. A pale ale disguised in a dark ale.

Dark hazel and very clear
decent hop nose, not much else
med/thin body and mildly fizzy
nettle hop flavour w/ some background malt
dry, bitter finish that leaves my mouth dry
okay. maybe it has a place but at the moment im not a fan.

Bottle.  Dark copper with a medium foam.  Aromas are zesty dark berries with bubblegum and floral notes.  Toffee malts with clean grapefruit.  Toast and rye bread with light burnt notes.  Flavours are sweet and juicy, fruity malts with berries and grapefruit.  Toasted and dry on the finish with some nuttiness.  Decent.

Cask (Rake, London)
6- Malty aroma.
4 Deep red, persistent beige head.
6 Beautiful rich hoppy malty body. More hops than an average mild, but Im not complaining at all.
4 Full palate, soft carbonation. Finish pleasantly roasty, and a little tingle of bitterness too..
13 More of a dark bitter than a mild, because of the higher hopping. And a good sessionable malty bitter it is too.

Cask at the Jolly Butchers, London on 2nd February 2011. Ruby with an off-white, part-lacing froth head. Berries aroma. In-mouth tastes of berries, Stilton and roast malts. Fruity and bitter finish; raspberries and strawberries with upper-mouth bitterness. Althouhg initially creamy, the mouthfeel becomes dry.

Yum. Very rich. Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a thick off-white head. Faint charred, fruity aroma with a bit of coffee. Full-bodied with blackcurrant, roasted coffee and a nice bitterness.

Cask Conditioned	air pressure	Euston Tap	London.  A black beer with a white head.  A hoppy dark beer.  Excellent citrus notes in the nose.  More roasty in the mouth from the dark malts but the hoppiness is there again.  An accomplished tasty beer.

MIni-cask that my dad got from the brewery late November 2010 we consumed much of this on his birthday 26.12.10 Cheers dad!   Pours dark brown with a nice frothy beige head. Fruity and bitter, nice and tangy, dry and full of berry tastes. Nice beer had to have a few of these.  A6 A4 T7 P4 Ov15  3.5

Cask at the Euston Tap. Dark garnet pour with a thick, foamy, off-white head. Roasted malt aroma. Flavor is lightly sweet with some charred malts, light minerality, some dry, roasty bitterness. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Finishes malty and roasty, some burnt wood, light, earthen hops. Pretty solid brew.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2011 Bottles from The Scottish Real Ale Shop & Beers of Europe. Sweet fruity aroma. Very dark brown colour with a good head. Metallic roasted malt & liquorice  flavour. Bitter aftertaste. A good mild.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a  fruity malty caramel aroma with hoppy hints. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish with hoppy hints in the aftertaste .

[cask at the 2009 Scottish Real Ale Festival] Dark ruby ale with so much fruit in the malt its pretty surprising. The hops come and go, and the richness of flavour give it a great lasting finish. Definitely get the advertised blackcurrant on the aftertaste. Its fantastically drinkable, and a prime example of a session beer that isnt pale and slightly hoppy [28062009]

from tap (uncommonly fyne ale), dark brown/reddish colour, small and unstable white and a bit lacing head. Almost no sparkles within the beer. Smell: hoppy, roasted malt. Taste: roasted malts, powerfull bitterness, hoppy, dry aftertaste.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2010 Cask.  The Bree Louise, London. Brown colour with a beige head.  Aroma of malt sweetness, light roastiness, caramel, and some hops. Flavor of maltiness, light roast, fruit, coffee, caramel, toffee, citrus. More roasted and dry towards the finish. Smoother on cask than bottle. Re-rated 100201. Tasty!

A Mes rate.Cask at Ye Olde Mitre Tavern.Chestnut brown with a thin beige head. Really well balanced dark lager. Full of earthy malt and really good grassy hops. A good blend of floral and caramel with an excellent bitter finish. Really dry, very drinkable. Really good.
Cask @ 3 Judges. Brown - dark red colour, tan head. Aroma is fruity (lemonade, forest fruits, berries?) and hoppy. Flavour is fruity, with bitter malts and hops. Bitter finish.

Bottle 50cl.Clear medium brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, milk chocolate. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. finish feel is light metalic. [20090514]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Clear orangey brown with a small beige head. Fresh citrusy hops in the nose. Light body with dried fruits, roasted malt and very distinct citrusy hops that leave a solid bitterness. Excellent - but not really your typical Mild. 140509

Bottle, shared by Papsoe. It pours a clear, copper body under a small, beige head. Lovely resiny hops in the aroma, with some roasted malt in the back. The flavor has a nice blend of hops and caramel malt, with resin, pinecones and a nice bitterness. Full-bodied. Bitter finish. A really nice one, showing that also the Scots can use lots of hops if they want to. (090514)
Botella. Clear dark brown. Sweet caramel malty roasty aroma. Sweet caramel quite hoppy malty flavour. Dry bitter finish.
Bottle, 4.4%. Vinous aroma. Clear dark brown colour. Good malty aroma. Quite bitter, but clean. Good maltiness to the flavour, a little soy.

Clear dark amber with a medium beige head. Aroma had milk chocolate, caramel and roasted malt. Flavour was quite hoppy and had roasted malt, caramel, pine and grapefruit towards the end. Finished bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 Cask @ London Drinker 25:

A dark and ruddy brew, very moody.

Lovely fresh fruit, blackcurrant. Sweet and childish aromas.

Bitter and wicked after the teasing aromas. It really turns on you. It still has loads of fruit but some of the whole tongue bitterness that I love, even if it is a bit dry.

Quite thin but with a cute tingly carbonation.

Lovely. Even if it is a little deceptive it feels good to be teased.

Not quite as banging in the bottle. 15/07/09
Cask at The London Drinkers Festival 2009. Dark brown with a frothy head. Nice fruity hop aroma, hints of grapefruit. Grapefruity flavours, bitter. Likeable spark.

Cask-conditioned at the Portcullis, Bristol 26/1/09. Deep amber with a slight, off-white head.  Fruity, roasted malts and caramel sweetness in the aroma. Flavour was also sweet, with dark fruit and nuts and an uplifting hoppy, dry finish. Very good.

Half, cask served by air pressure dispense at The Bow Bar. Low off-white head on top of a very dark rosewood body. Quite appealing smell of dark fruits. Flavoured with sappy grapefruits, carefully joined by earthy malts. Well rounded bitter ending. Good beer, however a bit thin in the mouth [Sunday pub crawl in Edinburgh, 26.10.2008. And a bottle at my room in St Andrews 06.11.2008]

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2009 From cask. Pours clear and deep amber, yet golden. Mild malty and roasted with a distinct hoppy note. Solid roasted malt flavoured with a solid bitterness coming through and with a minor liqourice note. Mild spiced hoppy and acidic bitter to dry finish.

Cask, Village Inn, Arrochar.  Dark chestnut colour with a thin off white head. Aroma lovely, lots of dark christmas fruit with a healthy dose of malt. Full bodied and very smooth.  Great long, dry finish. The first one didn’t touch the sides. Delicious. A cracker.
Bottle. Dark and malty with a quite pleasant sharpness.Some bitterness and overall quite reasonable.Its nice to find this style in a bottle.

500ml filtered bottle in Loch Long Hotel. "A very dark rich ale". A dark ale, more in line with a mild than a stout perhaps. Theres a pleasant roasty quality, a decent smoothness, and a light fruit wrapped up in a dry but not biting finish. A very pleasing and well held together ale. Probably the best of the Fyne Ales.
Gravity Cask @ Guide Dog Beer Festival. Copper. Toasty verging on roasted malts with clean fruit sweetness. Some bitterness and slight fruit tartness.

Cask at Market Porter.  Dark brown beer with a thin tan head.  Aroma is quite faint and thin.  A bit of coffee and toasted malt but overall it lacks a lot of character.  Some earthy character and a fairly assertive bitterness.  Kind of boring.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 Deep red colour, rich smokey malt aroma, little bitter fruit nice but not quite there.
TK2 deep dark red ... little spicy fruit and rich smooth malts bit better but still not quite there 2.9->3.2

copper brown .... sweet toffee big hop ... big zezty hop with soft tofffee up to 3.6

cask at cloisters ... copper brown  ... thin tan head ... sweet toffee roast ... juicy malt nose .... soft mellow malt fruits ... mellow juicy ... very drinkable.. juicy blackcurrant ... real nice 4.0

Its a beautiful black/brown beer with a moderate head. The aroma has notes of caramel and light sweetness. The flavour has notes of roasted malt, caramel, licorice, berries and a light sweetness. The finish is rather dry. A truly nice beer!!

Bottle. Deep ruby red, good off white head and gentle condition. Pleasantly fruity aromas of raisins, some toffee sweetness and roasted barley, gentle burnt fruit in the mouth with a touch of caramel sweetness, some butteriness emerging in the finish.
[Cask from JDW] Caramel nose, with marzipan and berry fruits, background citric hop note. Light and dry with a little sweetness, leaves toasty malt on the palate.
Cask at Bedford BF 06. Floral hop aroma. Rather a dull, thin, slightly soapy taste. Some slight bitterness. Last day of the Festival. I suspect this was past its best.
Aroma hits me with roasted almonds to a certain level, with floural hops. Taste is burnt with the floral hops running around also.

Cask (gravity dispense) at Battersea Beer Festival. A dark, chewy bitter. Deep chestnut brown colour. Warming, rich, fruity aroma. Fruit cake notes on the palate, quite full bodied finishing dry and long bitter aftertaste. Lots of nuances for a bitter. A nice beer in tip top condition.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Beer Festival. Nice soft, toasty dark fruit characters, with a dry, softly bitter finish, the flavour seems to last a while, which was nice. Very good.

Cask conditioned, gravity at Battersea Beer Festival 2006.  I think this was my highest rated UK beer of the festival and it wasnt even on the list!!!  Chestnut colour with thin beige head.  Lovely aroma, nutty/dates/fruit and deep malt.  Good malts in mouth.  Drying finish.  In fact my notes say, Best UK beer so far.  Soft in mouth with a salty bitterness, again as Duff so rightly said.

Cask Handpump at the Bhurtpore Inn, Aston 09/07/2005
Mid brown coloured slightly strong in alcohol. Fruity bubble gum flavour. Some dryness in a bitter lasting finish.
Cask. Deep brown color with a white head. The taste is a sweet light malty body with light nutty and roasted notes.

[Cask at GBBF 2005] A red-brown beer with a tin off-white head. The aroma is sweet with light notes of roasted malt as well as hints of diacethyl. The flavor is sweet roasted with light notes of prunes, leading to a dry roasted end.
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2006 A little dark, it was squashy, but not like that, I enjoyed a little bit, and perhaps because it was dark.

Cask at the Swan in the Rushes, Loughborough. 
No; it is not a bitter.
Dark ruby coloured. Creamy white head. 
Tastes like a fairly good porter.

Cask condioned GBBF 2005:
Tastes like a quite thin porter. Fruity aroma, toffee notes in the finish. A strange beer, not particary bitter.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Burton upon Trent Beer Festival.  Reddish black beer with a a lightly hopped aroma and a toffee/caramel flavour with a very dry bitter finish.  Overall an OK beer.
Hand pull at Babington Arms (JDW) Derby. Deep brown/black with scant head, slight malty stoutness in the nose doesnt deliver any greater bitterness until a short finish. Ho hum.

Bottled bright, from the St. Albans, Beer Festival.  Deep brown colour with a reddish hue. Generous rustic malt aroma. Slight metallic notes amongst organic malts and mineral flavours. Late arriving bitterness is almost none existent at the start but builds nicely on and to the finish.
